autograph.title: Sonata a quattro no. 4
autograph.notes: Probably a copy, but extremely interesting on account of the detailed accuracy with which the text, the slurs and the expression-marks are recorded. Is it possible that these details are in the hand of Boccherini? In any case, the MS. appears to have been copied from Boccherini's original MS.

autograph.title: Sonata a quattro no. 9
autograph.description: Separate parts. Probably a copy, but extremely interesting on account of the detailed accuracy with which the text, the slurs and the expression-marks are recorded. Is it possible that these details are in the hand of Boccherini? In any case, the MS. appears to have been copied from Boccherini's original MS.

ms_copies_parts.title: Quartetto no. 3
ms_copies_parts.description: A most interesting manuscript, of which the text is identical to that of the manuscript in Lucca, although the order of the works is different. The cover has a note 'Per S.A.R. Monsignore il Principe Hereditario di Prussia', i.e. the future Frederick William II.

ms_copies_parts.title: Opera III- Concerto terzo
ms_copies_parts.description: The viola and 'cello parts are in the hand of an eighteenth-century copyist; the handwriting of the two violin parts resembles that of Boccherini.

entries.notes: In Boccherini's autograph catalogue (for comment, see below). The MS. bears the stamps of the collections of Louis Picquot and Charles Malherbe. The composition of these quartets, which mark an important date in the evolution of Boccherini's style, must have been spread over a relatively long period. The date on the MS. has been scratched out by Boccherini himself. He first wrote 'op. 111a de 1776' and then altered this to 'op. 1a de 1777'. Eventually, when he drew up a thematic catalogue of his works, he listed these quartets under the year 1778 with the number Op. 24. We do not know the reason for these changes; but the first date makes it clear that the six works were composed—if not in their final form, at least in their general spirit—as early as the middle of the year 1776.

entries.notes: Unpublished in Boccherini's life-time. The origin of the title 'La Tiranna' is unknown. There is no doubt that the words are in the hand of Boccherini. Titles of this kind are so rare that we may be sure that they denote a precise intention on the part of the composer. Two or three explanations have been suggested for the present title. Some say that it is borrowed from a work by Goya, the portrait (now in the Academia de Bellas Artes in Madrid) of the actress Rosario Fernandez, who was known as 'La Tirana'. According to others, it is a reference to 'la tirana', the name of a popular dance and also of a slow melody; the trio of the minuet corresponds well to this last explanation. What is certain is the very Spanish character of the work, with a strong contrast between the nervous vivacity of the Presto and the sombre melancholy of the minuet.

entries.notes: No reference in Boccherini's autograph catalogue. At the beginning of this MS. is a note (19th century) in English: 'N.B.—This manuscript is very correctly and carefully written, and may possibly be the hand writing of Dr Haydn; 1st from the close resemblance to his style as recorded, and 2ndly from the constant intercourse between these two eminent composers transmission to each other of their works (sic)'. The tradition that close relations existed between Haydn and Boccherini is discussed in the Biography. With regard to the present MS. we have consulted two scholars with special knowledge of Haydn, Messrs. Anthony van Hoboken and Karl Geiringer. The opinion of both is that the handwriting of the score of these six quartets, though very similar to that of Haydn, is not his nor that of any of his regular amanuenses. Moreover, there is no known instance of Haydn having arranged a series of works by another musician, even a friend. Whoever transcribed the score appears to have added certain words (though not the note quoted above) in English, and we are inclined to believe that the arrangements are the work of an English amateur of the beginning of the 19th century.

entries.notes: TWO QUARTETS for two violins, viola and 'cello (arrangements of two quintets). No reference in Boccherini's autograph catalogue. These two quartets cannot be considered authentic. The arrangement, which is very correctly done, is the work of an unknown musician of the 18th century. No. 1. Quartet in D Minor: Allegro moderato—Lento—Allegro. Arrangement of the whole of the quintet Op. 18 no. 5 of 1774 (No. 287). No. 2. Quartet in Bb Major: Allegro giusto—Adagio assai cantabile—Minuetto con moto—Prestissimo. Arrangement of the whole of the quintet Op. 20 no. 2 of 1775 (No. 290). Unpublished.

Incorrectly attributed to Boccherini? Described by Picquot (p. 167) in the following words, which are our only source of information for this quartet: 'Quite recently, I received information of a quartet attributed to this composer, of which the motif is as follows:' As all the manuscripts of this author, without exception, bear the date of their composition, I did not doubt that the date on the manuscript would put me on the path of truth, if it corresponded to the year 1795. I did not rest, therefore, until I had got possession of this manuscript, which was in the hands of an amateur

entries.notes: THREE QUARTETS (Op. 5) for flute, violin, viola and 'cello. No reference in Boccherini's autograph catalogue. Arrangements by Pleyel (?) or Cambini (?) of three double 'cello quintets. No. 1: Quartet in D Major: Allegro vivace—Tempo di Minuetto—Larghetto—Finale presto. Arrangement of the whole of the quintet in Eb Major Op. 49 no. 5 of 1794 (No. 369). No. 2: Quartet in G Major: Andante lento—Minuetto—Allegro con brio—Andante lento and Allegro. Arrangement of the whole of the quintet in F Major Op. 46 no. 5 of 1793 (No. 363). No. 3: Quartet in D Minor: Moderato assai—Minuetto—Adagio non tanto—Finale presto. Arrangement of the whole of the quintet in D Minor Op. 49 no 4 of 1794 (No. 368). No MSS. of any kind are known.

sources.first_edition: Paris, Boyer-Naderman (n.d.)

entries.notes: SIX QUARTETS for flute, violin, viola and 'cello. Arrangements. No reference in Boccherini's autograph catalogue. For comment as to authenticity, see below. Boyer-Naderman published two books of three quartets each, but no copy of this edition has been found. Picquot comments that the early quartets of Boccherini have furnished the framework for these works without merit, in which a flute part has been substituted by way of transposition for the part of the first violin, completely distorting the character and effect of the works.

sources.first_edition: Paris, Bouillon (c. 1825) - Trois quatuors pour flûte, clarinette, cor et basson extraits des oeuvres de Boccherini dédiés à Monsieur Camille Canuel, Avocat, par Othon Van den Broek pensionnaire de la Chapelle du Roi et de l'Académie Royale de musique, Livre 3ème, à Paris, chez Bouillon, rue du Doyenné no 12

entries.notes: THREE QUARTETS (nos. 7 to 9) for clarinet, flute, horn and bassoon. Arrangements by Othon Van den Broek. No. 1. Quartet in F Major: Allegro moderato—Andante—Rondo. No. 2. Quartet in C Major: Allegro moderato—Andantino—Rondo. No. 3. Quartet in D Minor: Allegro maestoso—Andante con variazioni—Tempo di minuetto (trio). None of these movements corresponds to any movement of a known work by Boccherini. It is impossible to reach any conclusion as to the origin of these arrangements. Were they derived by Van den Broek from manuscripts or editions of works by Boccherini—or falsely attributed to Boccherini—which are unknown to us? Or did he perhaps wish to give the prestige of Boccherini's name to works of his own production? In any case, it may be remarked that the musical value of this third collection is very inferior to that of the two preceding books (Nos. 262 and 263).
